titleStmt.title: SII 2.91: original edition by V. Venkayya
No. 91. ON THE NORTH WALL OF THE CENTRAL SHRINE, LOWER TIER. No. 36 of 1897.

summary.p: This inscription contains a list of silver utensils presented by king Rājarājadēva to the temple. They are said to have borne the names Śivapādaśēgaraṉ and Śrī-RājarājaṉThese names are not used in the body of the inscription for the utensils presented. There seems to be a reference to the conferment of these two titles on the king in No. 1, paragraph 55. The king is said to have presented a number of trumpets made of gold on the occasion. and to have been procured from three sources, viz. (1) the king's treasures, (2) the booty acquired in the war against the Chēra king and the Pāṇḍyas in Malai-nāḍu and (3) the silver seized in the same campaign. The list, however, begins with the gifts made from the treasures seized after defeating the Chēra king and the Pāṇḍyas in Malai-nāḍu. No mention of the other two items occurs in the preserved portion of the inscription. But as lines 2 to 4 are considerably damaged, causing almost the complete disappearance of several paragraphs in each case, we cannot be quite sure that the other two items are not mentioned. In fact, as the enumeration of the vessels is repeated in different parts of the inscription, it may be presumed that the other items are also referred to in the damaged portions. For instance, bowls (maṇḍai) are enumerated in paragraphs 43 to 59 and in paragraphs 128-9; censers (kalaśappāṉai) in paragraphs 65 to 75 as well as in paragraph 122; small baskets in paragraph 81 as well as in 130; spittoons (paḍikkam) in paragraph 107 as well as in 139. It is very unlikely that the utensils described in the latter part of the inscription were omitted by mistake when the earlier part was engraved. At the end of the inscription three images of Śrī-Vāsudēva made of silver are mentioned. Perhaps these were made from the silver seized in the campaign against the Chēra king and the Pāṇḍyas in Malaināḍu. The gold emblems, corals and ornaments seized in the same war are referred to in No. 1, paragraph 51, No. 3, paragraphs 5 and 6, No. 59, paragraphs 2, 3, 4, 9 and 11 and in No. 93 below.

It is worthy of note that this is the only inscription of the temple which mentions presents made of silver. Most of the other inscriptions record gifts of gold. It looks as if the king had more gold and precious stones at his disposal than silver.

revisionDesc.change: Further conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)
Conversion of digital encoding to DHARMA encoding scheme according to EGD (Encoding Guide for Diplomatic Editions)

div.p:
svasti śrī . śrīrājarājīśvaramuṭaiya paramasvāmikku Uṭaiyār śrīrājarājadevar tam paṇṭāraṅkaḷil kuṭutta veḷḷiyiṉ tirupparikalaṅkaḷuḷḷiṭṭaṉavum ceramāṉaiyum pāṇṭiyarkaḷaiyum malaināṭṭu Eṟin=tu koṇṭa veḷḷiyiṉ tirupparikalaṅkaḷuḷḷiṭṭaṉavum Ivarkaḷaiye Eṟin=tu koṇṭa veḷḷi koṇṭu ceyta tirupparikalaṅkaḷuḷḷiṭṭaṉavum śivapādacekaraṉeṉṟum śrīrājarājaṉeṉṟum tirunāmam Uṭaiyaṉa yāṇṭu Irupattoṉpatāvatu varai kuṭutta veḷḷiyiṉ tirupparikalaṅkaḷuḷḷiṭṭaṉa Āṭavallāṉeṉṉu[m kallāl niṟai Eṭuttu kallil veṭṭiṉa —?] 1 ceramāṉaiyum pāṇṭiyarkaḷaiyum malaināṭṭu Eṟin=tu koṇṭa paṇ[ṭāraṅkaḷil kuṭuttaṉa ?] [—2*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Eḻu O [.. 3*] [kāḷa ?] [—4*] [—5*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Orukaḻañcarai [—6*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Orukaḻañcey [—7*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟut[toṇṇūṟṟu ?] Eḻukaḻañcarai— 8 kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi [irunūṟṟu ?]ttoṇṇūṟṟu Irukaḻañcarai— 9 kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Eṇpattorukaḻañcey mukkāl— [10*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Eḻupattu Oṉpatiṉ kaḻañcey mukkāl— [10 1*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupattaiyṅkaḻa[ñcu ?]— [10 2*] kāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Eṇkaḻañcey Oṉpatu mañcāṭiyuṅkuṉṟi [—] [10 3*]
[taḷikai ?] Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eḻupattu mukkaḻañcu— [10 4*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eṇpattirukaḻañcu [—] [10 5*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eṇpattorukaḻañcu— [10 6*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eṇpatiṉ kaḻañcu— [10 7*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eḻupattu E[ṇ kaḻañcu—?] [10 8*] [taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi ?] toḷāyirattu Eḻupattu Eḻukaḻañcarai— [10 9*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eḻupattu mukkaḻañcarai— [2 10*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eḻupattorukaḻañcu— [2 10 1*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Eḻupatiṉ kaḻañ[cu—] [2 10 2*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu Aṟupattu [nāṟ ?]kaḻañcu— [2 10 3*]As the number of paragraphs lost here cannot be ascertained, they have been ignored altogether in the subsequent numbering. The actual measurement of the portion damaged in the impression shows that about four items are lost in the gap. [taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi ?] [— 2 10 4*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟu Orukaḻañ[cu—] [2 10 5*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟoṉpatiṉ kaḻañcu— [2 10 6*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu Aṟupattorukaḻañcu— [2 10 7*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu muppattorukaḻañcu— [2 10 8*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Eṇpattorukaḻañcarai— [2 10 9*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Orupattu Eḻukaḻañcu— [3 10*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu
Eṇpattu Eḻukaḻañcu— [3 10 1*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Eṇpattu nāṟka[ḻañcu—] [3 10 2*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Eḻupatiṉ kaḻañcu— [3 10 3*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Aṟupattirukaḻañcu —[3 10 4*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Orupattirukaḻañcarai[—] [3 10 5*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟirukaḻañcāka Iraṇṭiṉāl veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Eṇpattu nāṟkaḻañ[cu—] [3 10 6*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Eṇpattu Oṉpatiṉ kaḻañcu [—] [3 10 7*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Eṇpattaiyṅkaḻañcu— [3 10 8*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Eḻupattu [eṇ ?]kaḻañcu— [3 10 9*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Aṟupattu Aṟukaḻañcarai— [4 10*] taḷikai Oṉṟu veḷḷi kaḻañcu— [4 10 1*] taḷikai Oṉṟu [—4 10 2*]As in line 2, the number of paragraphs actually lost here cannot be ascertained. They have, therefore, been entirely ignored in the subsequent numbering. But the actual measurement of the damaged portion shows that probably four items have been lost in the gap. maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟu Orukaḻañcu— [4 10 3*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu pattu mukkaḻañcu— [4 10 4*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu nāṟpatiṉ kaḻañcu— [4 10 5*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupatteḻukaḻañcu [—] [4 10 6*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupattaṟukaḻañ[cu—] [4 10 7*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupattaiyṅkaḻañcāka nāliṉālThe sign of length of ḷā appears to be corrected from the vowel ā . toḷḷāyirakkaḻañcu— [4 10 8*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu
veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupattu nāṟkaḻañcāka Iraṇṭināl veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu nāṟpatteṇkaḻañcu— [4 10 9*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu [muppattu ?] mukkaḻañcāka Iraṇṭināl veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu [aṟupat ?]tu Aṟukaḻañcu— [5 10*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupattoru kaḻañcu— [5 10 1*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Irupatiṉ kaḻañcu— [5 10 2*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Orupattonpatiṉ kaḻañcāka Iraṇṭināl veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu muppatteṇkaḻañcu [—] [5 10 3*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Orupattu Eṇkaḻañcu— [5 10 4*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Orupatteḻukaḻañcu— [5 10 5*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi [iru ?]nūṟṟu Orupattu Aiṅkaḻa[ñcu—] [5 10 6*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Orupattu [— 5 10 7*]The number of paragraphs actually lost in the damaged portion cannot be ascertained. But from the measurement of the gap it appears that four items have been lost. They are, however, not taken into account in the subsequent numbering of the paragraphs. A few aksharas which are visible of two of the paragraphs have been inserted in the text. Irunūṟṟu Orupattu [—*] Eṇpa cu—maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟeḻupattu Eḻukaḻañcarai— [5 10 8*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Aṟupattu Aiyṅkaḻañcu— [5 10 9*] kuṭam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Eḻunūṟṟu Aiṅkaḻañcu [—6 10*] kuṭam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aṟunūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟu Irukaḻañcu— [6 10 1*] kuṭam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aṟunūṟṟu Irupatiṉ kaḻañcu— [6 10 2*] kuṭam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟu Aiṅkaḻañcu— [6 10 3*] kuṭam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟukkaḻañcu— [6 10 4*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi ttu Iru
patiṉkaḻañcu— [6 10 5*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi toḷāyirattu teṇkaḻañcu— [6 10 6*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Eḻunūṟṟu Orupatiṉ kaḻañcu [—] [6 10 7*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu [itani ?]l curukkiṉa poṉ nāṟkaḻañcey kuṉṟi Uṭpaṭa veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟu Aimpatteṇkaḻañcu [—] [6 10 8*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟu muppatteḻukaḻañcu— [6 10 9*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi The existing traces of letters point to the reading aiññūṟṟu. nāṟkaḻañcu— [7 10*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi ṟu Eḻupattorukaḻañcu— [7 10 1*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aṟupatiṉ kaḻañ[cu—] [7 10 2*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu nūṟṟu nāṟpattaṟukaḻañcu— [7 10 3*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu Eḻupattoṉpatiṉ kaḻañcu— [7 10 4*] kalacappāṉai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu nāṟpattu [kaḻañcu—] [7 10 5*]Here as well as in the corresponding portion of the following four lines there is a big gap which must have been occupied by the description of five or six items in each line. These have been ignored in the subsequent numbering of the paragraphs. [mūkkuvaṭṭakai ?] Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu Orupattorukaḻañcu— [7 10 6*] mūkkuvaṭṭakai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṉūṟṟu E cu— [7 10 7*] mū[kkuvaṭṭakai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu ?] muppattoṉpatiṉ kaḻañcāka Iraṇṭināl veḷḷi Irunūṟṟu Eḻupatteṇkaḻañcu— [7 10 8*] mūkkuvaṭṭakai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟorupatiṉkaḻañcu— [7 10 9*] mūkkuvaṭṭakai Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟeḻupattaiyṅkaḻañcarai[—] [8 10*]
kaiyvaṭṭakai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiññūṟṟu Aṟupatteḻukaḻañcarai [—] [8 10 1*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aimpattaṟukaḻañcarai— [8 10 2*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aimpattirukaḻañcey kāl [—] [8 10 3*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aimpattorukaḻañcu— [8 10 4*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aimpatiṉ kaḻañcarai— [8 10 5*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṟpattaiyṅkaḻañcarai— [8 10 6*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi kaḻañcu— [8 10 7*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṟpattu mukkaḻañcu— [8 10 8*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṟpattorukaḻañcarai— [8 10 9*] [vaṭṭil Oṉ ?]ṟu veḷḷi nāṟpatiṉ kaḻañcarai— [9 10*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi muppatte[ṇkaḻañca ?]āka Iraṇṭināl veḷḷi [eḻupatta ?]ṟukaḻañcu— [9 10 1*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi [—9 10 2*]See the preceding note. kaḻañcu— [9 10 3*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupattu Oṉpatiṉ kaḻañ[cu—] [9 10 4*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi kaḻañcarai— [9 10 5*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupattaṟukaḻañcu— [9 10 6*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupattaiyṅkaḻañcāka mūṉṟināl veḷḷi Eḻupattaiyaṅkaḻañcu— [9 10 7*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupattu nāṟkaḻañcey mu [—] [9 10 8*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Iru
patiṉ kaḻañcey mukkālāka Iraṇṭināl veḷḷi nāṟpattorukaḻañcarai— [9 10 9*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupatiṉ kaḻañcarai— [100*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi patiṉe [—] [100 1*] vaṭṭil Oṉṟu veḷḷi muppatteḻuka[ḻañcu—] [100 2*] maṭal Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupattoṉpatiṉ kaḻañcu— [100 3*] piṅkāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Aiympattu Oṉpatiṉ kaḻañcu— [100 4*] piṅkāḷam Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Aimpattu Aiṅkaḻañcu— [100 5*] kaccolam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irupatteḻu kaḻañcarai— [100 6*] paṭikkam Oṉṟu veḷ]ḷi Eḻunūṟṟu Orupattu mukkaḻañcu— [100 7*] Oṉṟu veḷḷi Aiñ kaḻañcu [—] [100 8*] [paṭikkam ?] kuṇ mūṉṟum vaḷaiyil Iraṇṭu Oṉṟu veḷḷi muṉṉūṟṟu [100 9*]See note 2 on this page. ceppu Oṉṟu veḷḷi muppattirukaḻañcarai— [100 10*] cceppu ṟṟu mpatiṉ ka[ḻañcu—] [100 10 1*] Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu Eḻupattu Eṇkaḻañcu— [100 10 2*] caṭṭuvam Oṉṟu veḷḷi nūṟṟu nāṟpattu Orukaḻañcu— [100 10 3*] caṭṭuvam Oṉṟu veḷḷi Eḻupattu mukkaḻañcarai— [100 10 4*] neymuṭṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Eṇpattu Eḻukaḻañcu— [100 10 5*] neymuṭṭai

The letters [ka]ḻañcarai ||—are just seen at the end of the gap. maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunū[ṟṟuttoṇṇū ? ṟṟu Aṟukaḻañ[carai ..] [100 2 10 8*] maṇṭai Oṉṟu veḷḷi Irunūṟṟuttoṇṇūṟṟu Orukaḻañcey kāl .. ṟukkaḻañcarai .. [100 3 10 3*] taṭṭam Oṉṟu veḷḷi nāṟpatteṇkaḻañcey mukkālāka mūṉṟināl veḷḷi nūṟṟu nāṟpattu Aṟukaḻañcey kāl .. Hail ! Prosperity ! The sacred silver utensils (tirupparigalam), etc., bearing the sacred names Śivapādaśēgaraṉ and Śrī-Rājarājaṉ presented by the lord Śrī-Rājarājadēva until the twenty-ninth year (of his reign) to the supreme lord of the Śrī-Rājarājēśvara (temple),—(viz.) (1) the sacred silver utensils, etc., presented from his (own) treasures (2) the sacred silver utensils, etc.,The phrase veḷḷiyiṉ tirupparikalaṅkaḷuḷḷiṭṭaṉa is repeated three times in the original for the sake of clearness. seized after defeating the Chēra king and the Pāṇḍyas in Malai-nāḍu and (3) the sacred utensils, etc., made from the silver acquired (as booty) after defeating the same (enemies)—[were engraved (i.e. recorded) on stone after (they) had been weighed with the stone] called Āḍavallāṉ.
2. (The following are) those [given] from the treasures seized after defeating the Chēra king and the Pāṇḍyas in Malai-nāḍu:—
3. One trumpet (kāḷam), (consisting of) three hundred and seven • • • • of silver.
